abs: Assessing the reliability of complex technological systems such as communication networks, transportation grids, and bridge networks is a dicult task. From a mathematical point of view, the problem of estimating network reliability belongs to the #P complexity class. As a consequence, no analytical solution for solving this problem in a reasonable time is known to exist and one has to rely on dierent approximation techniques. In this paper we focus on a well-known Sequential Monte Carlo algorithm Lomonosov's turnip method. Despite the fact that this method was shown to be ecient under some mild conditions, it is known to be inadequate for stable estimation of network reliability in a rare-event setting. To overcome this obstacle, we suggest a quite general combination of Sequential Monte Carlo and multi-level splitting. The proposed method is shown to bring a signicant variance reduction as compared to the turnip algorithm, is easy to implement and parallelize, and has a proven performance guarantee for some network ty-pologies. (Radislav Vaisman), kroese@maths.uq.edu.au (Dirk P. Kroese), elyager@bezeqint.net (Ilya B. Gertsbakh) 1
title: Splitting Sequential Monte Carlo for Ecient Unreliability Estimation of Highly Reliable Networks
